newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian stocks ignore bank policy, up on budget hopes.
newsitem.headline: Indian stocks ignore bank policy, up on budget hopes.

text.p: Indian stock markets on Tuesday shrugged off a central bank credit policy designed to lower interest rates as investors focused on efforts to form a new government and pass a pro-growth budget, analysts said.
"We consider it mildly favourable for the stock market," Paribas Capital Markets' strategist Rupa Bose said of the policy for the first half of 1997/98 (April-March).
Bose said the slack season credit policy was unlikely to have an immediate effect on equities.
Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Chakravarty Rangarajan told Reuters Television that capital markets would be boosted by the policy announcements that allowed banks to buy more company shares.
"Certain stipulations on bank lending against shares and investments in shares have been modified. All this will mean a boost to the capital market," Rangarajan said in an interview.
Bombay's benchmark index was steady after the announcements and closed 57.72 points, or 1.61 percent, higher at 3647.44.
Traders said news of a likely resolution to the ongoing political crisis remained uppermost in investors' minds, and that the RBI measures were largely anticipated.
"The market is up on hopes of an early end to political instability," said Sanat Dalal, a member broker at the Bombay Stock Exchange.

India's United Front coalition, backed by the Congress party's promise of renewed support, was trying to form a new government under a different leader to replace the defeated Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda.
The centre-left government lost a confidence vote last Friday after Congress withdrew its backing and demanded the alliance change its leader as a condition for resuming support.
Traders said the market's key concern was the passage of the pro-business 1997/98 federal budget that has been held hostage by the political turmoil.
"It's a good credit policy but there are no surprises -- positive or negative," said Sandeep Dixit, banking analyst at Lehman Brothers in Hong Kong.
"In terms of increasing credit demand from corporates, the policy has built up on what the budget did," Dixit said.
The federal budget announced on February 28 boosted business confidence by slashing corporate and personal taxes across the board.
"If the budget does not get passed, will we still see a pick-up in demand for credit?" Dixit asked.
Parliament has agreed to take up the budget in a special session next week.

The RBI said in its policy for the first six months of 1997/98 (April-March) that banks -- which previously invested in bonds, shares, debentures and preference shares -- must now invest this money entirely in ordinary shares.
Banks could lend this money to companies against shares as the firms waited for capital to be raised through a public issue, RBI said in a statement.
"I think interest rates will come down, because the steps taken in this policy will lead to an increase in the lendable resources of banks," Rangarajan told Reuters Television.
Soon after he spoke state-run Corporation Bank said it planned to cut is prime lending rate to 14.0 percent from 14.5 percent.
--Bombay Newsroom, 265 9000
